<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 645, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the stretching of a spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 120]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 128, 761, 388]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 401, 532, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 434, 146, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 433, 920, 467]]<|/det|>
The metre ruler is clamped in position near to the spring. Do **not** change the position of the metre ruler.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 481, 181, 498]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 481, 715, 498]]<|/det|>
The value \(l_0\) is the length of the spring when the load \(L\) is 0.0N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 510, 920, 543]]<|/det|>
Measure the unstretched length \(l_0\) of the spring. Do **not** include the loops at the ends of the spring in your measurement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 556, 584, 574]]<|/det|>
Record \(l_0\) in cm to the nearest mm in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 556, 920, 575]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 587, 181, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 587, 781, 606]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram of the spring to show clearly the length \(l_0\) of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 821, 920, 839]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 835, 146, 853]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 835, 541, 853]]<|/det|>
Suspend a load \(L = 1.0 \text{N}\) from the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 852, 594, 870]]<|/det|>
Record the new length \(l\) of the spring in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 867, 761, 885]]<|/det|>
Calculate the extension \(e\) of the spring using the equation \(e = (l - l_0)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 883, 479, 900]]<|/det|>
Record the value of \(e\) in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 898, 744, 916]]<|/det|>
Repeat the procedure using loads \(L = 2.0 \text{N}, 3.0 \text{N}, 4.0 \text{N}\) and 5.0N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 914, 584, 932]]<|/det|>
Record all the readings and results in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 42, 510, 58]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 72, 541, 88]]<|/det|>
Table 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 314, 920, 333]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 346, 146, 365]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 345, 571, 365]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(L / N\) ( \(y\)-axis) against \(e / \text{cm}\) ( \(x\)-axis).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 377, 334, 395]]<|/det|>
Draw the best-fit line.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 403, 792, 821]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 816, 920, 835]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 848, 146, 866]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 848, 920, 881]]<|/det|>

<form>e_{\mathrm{A}} = ............................................................ [2]

<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light using a semicircular transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. You may refer to Fig. 3.1 and Fig. 3.2 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 144, 824, 680]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 694, 532, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 725, 146, 743]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 725, 918, 758]]<|/det|>
Draw a line across the ray-trace sheet supplied, approximately in the middle. Label the line \(\mathbf{PQ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 756, 171, 774]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 755, 920, 789]]<|/det|>
Place the transparent block, largest face down, with the straight side on the line \(\mathbf{PQ}\) and the curved side below the line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 787, 173, 804]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 787, 920, 820]]<|/det|>
Draw round the outline of the block. Label the ends of the straight side of the block \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 817, 173, 835]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 817, 920, 850]]<|/det|>
Remove the block and draw the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) through the centre of \(\mathbf{AB}\). Continue the normal so that it passes through the curved side of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 848, 175, 866]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 848, 621, 866]]<|/det|>
Label the point \(\mathbf{C}\) where the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 865, 920, 883]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 72, 787, 90]]<|/det|>
Draw the line \(\mathbf{DC}\) at an angle \(i = 20^{\circ}\) to the normal, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 87, 475, 106]]<|/det|>
Place the paper on the pin board.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 170, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>*</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 102, 895, 119]]<|/det|>
Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), on line \(\mathbf{DC}\) at a suitable distance apart for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 117, 170, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>*</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 117, 918, 164]]<|/det|>
Replace the block and look from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 3.1 to observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{AB}\) of the block. Adjust your line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 163, 170, 181]]<|/det|>
<label>*</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 163, 920, 196]]<|/det|>
Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\), \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 195, 175, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>*</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 195, 526, 212]]<|/det|>
Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\), \(\mathsf{P}_2\), \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 211, 175, 228]]<|/det|>
<label>*</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 211, 460, 228]]<|/det|>
Remove the block and the pins.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 227, 171, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>*</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 227, 771, 244]]<|/det|>
Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line to \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 242, 175, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>*</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 242, 564, 260]]<|/det|>
Label \(\mathbf{E}\), the end of the line furthest from \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 259, 920, 277]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 146, 306]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 288, 920, 322]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> A student investigates the change in current in a conducting liquid as the distance between two electrodes is changed. The circuit is shown in Fig. 4.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 112, 675, 275]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 289, 532, 308]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 920, 355]]<|/det|> Plan an experiment to investigate the change in current in the liquid as the distance between the electrodes is changed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 485, 384]]<|/det|> You are **not** required to do this investigation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 397, 218, 415]]<|/det|> You should: <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 429, 144, 446]]<|/det|>
explain briefly how to do the investigation
state the key variables to keep constant
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are
not required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how to use your readings to reach a conclusion.
